title: Home
content:
Digital Methods Accelerator # Site index # The table below links to every area in the Accelerator and lists the associated practices so the content can be filled in later.
Strand Area Examples Core DH Skills Coding foundations Intro to coding (Python) Core DH Skills Data work Data wrangling; metadata; digital forensics Core DH Skills Text & cultural analytics Topic modelling; embeddings Core DH Skills Networked culture Network analysis Core DH Skills Digital collections Creating digital collections; digitisation workflows Core DH Skills Web methods Web scraping; APIs Core DH Skills Physical computing Raspberry Pis; sensors Core DH Skills Visual methods Data visualisation; exploratory vs explanatory graphics Core DH Skills Development foundations Collaborating on GitHub Core DH Skills Spatial GIS for humanities Core DH Skills Digitisation Digitisation, image to text, OCR Core DH Frames Critical lenses Feminist, queer, decolonial, anti-racist approaches Core DH Frames Accessibility Accessibility; critical disability studies Core DH Frames Data lifecycle E.g. acquire / transform / analyse / present / sustain Core DH Frames Formats, standards, etc. XML, JSON / Python, XSLT / SQL, SPARQL / TEI, IIIF Core DH Frames AI critique AI refusal, resistance, and abolition Core DH Frames Climate and environment Digital sustainability Core DH Frames What is tech? Intro to the tech sector; political economy of tech Core DH Frames Intro to stats Humanities data science Research Practice Open research Open research; open data; open software Research Practice Intro to experiments Randomization, bias, controls & blocking, factorial interaction Research Practice Intro to fieldwork Interviews, coding Research Practice Data governance GDPR; privacy; consent; data protection Research Practice Ethics & risk Research ethics; risk assessment; institutional review Research Practice Preservation Digital preservation; archiving; stewardship Research Practice IP & reuse Copyright; licensing; reuse Digital Media and Arts Creative coding CSS + HTML + JS; in-browser games Digital Media and Arts Games & narrative Twine; intro to game design; intro to Unity Digital Media and Arts Making & materiality 3D printing; soldering; code textiles Digital Media and Arts Design Speculative design, design thinking, prototyping Digital Media and Arts Security Intro to cybersecurity Digital Media and Arts Media archaeology Digital forensics, recovery from obsolete media Critical AI Practice Intro to making AI RAG methods, risks, and harms Critical AI Practice Carbon estimation CodeCarbon Critical AI Practice Distance reading AI summation methods, risks, and harms Critical AI Practice AI era media literacy Identifying genAI content SHL Digital Infrastructure To be defined SHL Digital Services To be defined SHL Digital Sustainability To be defined Software requirements # We have tried to use minimal software dependencies, a lightweight theme with simple HTML/CSS and github’s own actions as the site’s hosting infrastructure.
This site uses the Hugo CMS, the hugo-book theme, and github actions to build and publish the site on GitHub pages.
The hugo site configuration is in the config.yaml file. This contains theme specific parameters and some general hugo configuration settings.
The repository is configed to serve the site from the gh-pages branch of the repository, and the actions are configured in the .github/workflows/main.yml file to build and commit HTML output to that branch.
The main action must be triggered manually. This is to control/minimise the amount of devops actions container setup time the site uses.
The github action depends on 3 external actions from the Github marketplace: the github checkout action to checkout the repo into the action’s temporary container, peaceiris’ hugo actions to install hugo and build the site inside the container, and peaceiris’ github pages actions to put the built HTML content into the gh-pages branch of the repository where it can be hosted publically online.
Visit the project on GitHub

Software requirements #

We have tried to use minimal software dependencies, a lightweight theme with simple HTML/CSS and github’s own actions as the site’s hosting infrastructure.

title: Core DH Skills
content:
Core DH Skills # Coding foundations # Coding foundations introduce basic programming ideas and workflows that support humanities research, from scripting to reproducible analysis. The focus is on using code as a critical tool that makes assumptions visible and open to critique.
Resources will be added here.
Intro to coding (Python) Data work # Data work covers how humanities data is collected, cleaned, and described so it can be responsibly analyzed. It emphasizes provenance, documentation, and the ways data practices shape what can be known, especially in the context of bias and exclusion.
Resources will be added here.
Data wrangling Metadata Digital forensics Text & cultural analytics # Text and cultural analytics explore computational approaches to studying language and cultural patterns at scale. Methods are paired with critical perspectives that question training data, representational limits, and whose voices are amplified or silenced.
Resources will be added here.
Topic modelling Embeddings Networked culture # Networked culture examines how people, texts, and platforms connect and circulate. It combines network analysis with attention to power, mediation, and the politics of digital infrastructures.
Resources will be added here.
Network analysis Digital collections # Digital collections focus on building and maintaining collections that support research, teaching, and public access. The emphasis is on stewardship, access, and ethical care for cultural materials and communities.
Resources will be added here.
Creating digital collections Digitisation workflows Web methods # Web methods address how to gather and study web-based materials in ways that respect legal, ethical, and platform constraints. These methods treat the web as a dynamic cultural space shaped by algorithms and governance.
Resources will be added here.
Web scraping APIs Physical computing # Physical computing connects digital research to material devices and environments. It foregrounds how sensors and embedded systems shape the data we collect and how that data relates to place and lived experience.
Resources will be added here.
Raspberry Pis Sensors Visual methods # Visual methods explore how graphics and diagrams support interpretation and argument in the humanities. They focus on clarity, rhetoric, and the responsibilities of visual storytelling with data.
Resources will be added here.
Data visualisation Exploratory vs explanatory graphics Development foundations # Development foundations introduce collaborative practices that make digital projects sustainable. Version control and shared workflows support transparency, accountability, and collective scholarship.
Resources will be added here.
Collaborating on GitHub Spatial # Spatial methods use geographic tools to analyze place, movement, and spatial narratives in the humanities. They also consider how mapping choices can reinforce or challenge historical and cultural power relations.
Resources will be added here.
GIS for humanities Digitisation # Digitisation converts physical materials into digital forms that can be searched, analyzed, and shared. It includes attention to accuracy, labor, and the limits of automated recognition in cultural contexts.
Resources will be added here.
Digitisation Image to text OCR
summary:
Core DH Skills #

Coding foundations #

Coding foundations introduce basic programming ideas and workflows that support humanities research, from scripting to reproducible analysis. The focus is on using code as a critical tool that makes assumptions visible and open to critique.

Resources will be added here.

Data work #

Data work covers how humanities data is collected, cleaned, and described so it can be responsibly analyzed. It emphasizes provenance, documentation, and the ways data practices shape what can be known, especially in the context of bias and exclusion.
